DOC.HEAD: Consumer Commission Warns of Danger in Stuffed Animal
DOC.TEXT: The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that a stuffed animal Christmas toy sold to nearly 2 million people may present a hidden suffocation danger to young children. The warning involves the ``Velveteen Rabbit'' in a red Christmas stocking sold from Target Stores in 23 states. ``There is a plastic bag around the lower portion of the rabbit which may present a risk of suffocation to young children,'' the agency said in a written statement. Consumers should remove and discard the bag immediately, the commission said. The bag, which is not a part of the toy, is inside the stocking and ``may not be immediately noticed before the toy is given to a child,'' the commission said. The floppy-eared brown-and-white rabbits come in two sizes _ 8-inch and 12-inch _ and the bag on the larger rabbit could easily fit over the head of a small child, a commission staffer said. Approximately 1,750,000 of the toys, which meet all mandatory and voluntary packaging and toy safety standards, have been sold. The toy rabbits were sold in Missouri, Minnesota, Illinois, Michigan, Indiana, Ohio, Iowa, Oklahoma, Texas, Nevada, North Dakota, South Dakota, Colorado, Montana, Wyoming, Washington, California, Arizona, Louisiana, Tennessee, Arkansas, Florida and North Carolina. Consumers may contact Target Stores at 612-370-6000.
